|                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                           |                                                                                                   |
| **[Reference](/wiki/Source_code "Source code")**                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                          | [EvilHack - monst.c, line 3114](https://github.com/k21971/EvilHack/blob/master/src/monst.c#L3114) |

The **Rat King**, @, is a [unique](/wiki/Unique "Unique") [monster](/wiki/Monster "Monster") that appears in [EvilHack](/wiki/EvilHack "EvilHack") and [Hack'EM](/wiki/Hack%27EM "Hack'EM"). In Hack'EM, this version of the Rat King serves the same roles as [the Rat King](/wiki/The_Rat_King_\(SLASH%27EM\) "The Rat King (SLASH'EM)") of [SLASH'EM](/wiki/SLASH%27EM "SLASH'EM").

The Rat King is a [strong](/wiki/Strong "Strong") and [omnivorous](/wiki/Omnivorous "Omnivorous") [human](/wiki/Human_\(monster_attribute\) "Human (monster attribute)") that is similar to a [wererat](/wiki/Wererat "Wererat"), but does not shift from his [humanoid](/wiki/Humanoid "Humanoid") form. He has [regeneration](/wiki/Regeneration "Regeneration"), can be seen via [infravision](/wiki/Infravision "Infravision"), is capable of [swimming](/wiki/Swimming "Swimming"), and will pick up items and valuables.

The Rat King has a weapon attack and a [lycanthropy](/wiki/Lycanthropy "Lycanthropy")-inducing bite, and possesses [poison resistance](/wiki/Poison_resistance "Poison resistance"), [sleep resistance](/wiki/Sleep_resistance "Sleep resistance") and [drain resistance](/wiki/Drain_resistance "Drain resistance") like other werecreatures.

The Rat King's [corpse](/wiki/Corpse "Corpse") is [poisonous](/wiki/Poisonous "Poisonous") to eat.

[ ]

## Contents

- [1 Generation](#Generation)

  - [1.1 EvilHack](#EvilHack)
  - [1.2 Hack'EM](#Hack.27EM)

- [2 Strategy](#Strategy)

- [3 Origin](#Origin)

- [4 Encyclopedia entry](#Encyclopedia_entry)

## Generation

The Rat King is always generated hostile, and is not a valid form for normal [polymorph](/wiki/Polymorph "Polymorph").

The Rat King is always generated with a pair of [high boots](/wiki/High_boots "High boots"), a [cloak of displacement](/wiki/Cloak_of_displacement "Cloak of displacement"), and a [rustproof](/wiki/Rustproof "Rustproof") +1 to +3 [scimitar](/wiki/Scimitar "Scimitar") [of venom](/wiki/Object_properties#EvilHack "Object properties"). He also has a 2⁄3 chance of generating with a [ring of teleport control](/wiki/Ring_of_teleport_control "Ring of teleport control").

### EvilHack

The Rat King only appears in The Sewers of Waterdeep variant of [Mines' End](/wiki/Mines%27_End "Mines' End"), which is a [sewage](/wiki/Sewage "Sewage")-filled level consisting of a series of rooms that are surrounded by long halls, including a treasure room that is only accessible with [teleportation](/wiki/Teleportation "Teleportation") - he will always be generated in the throne room.

### Hack'EM

The Rat King appears on the [rat level](/wiki/Rat_level "Rat level") as he does in SLASH'EM and other similar variants, though he can still generate with a ring of teleport control as in EvilHack.

## Strategy

The Rat King is a formidable early-game opponent: He moves at the same base [speed](/wiki/Speed "Speed") as an unburdened player, resists sleep and poison that some early characters can use to dispatch other foes, and his weapon and cloak make him difficult to attack in melee. Even characters that can consistently hit through the Rat King's [AC](/wiki/AC "AC"), which is usually around 0, the [displacement](/wiki/Displacement "Displacement") from his [cloak](/wiki/Cloak "Cloak") will cause half of your attacks to miss - combined with the slowing effects of wading through sewage, this can easily prolong the fight and increase the odds of contracting lycanthropy, being poisoned by his scimitar, or simply taking excessive damage. A character with poison resistance, high [MC](/wiki/MC "MC") and consistent damage output should be able to take him on, and an early source of [flight](/wiki/Flight "Flight") or [levitation](/wiki/Levitation "Levitation") can help prevent the sewage from constantly slowing down non-[tortle](/wiki/Tortle_\(starting_race\) "Tortle (starting race)") characters.

[Ranged attacks](/wiki/Ranged_attack "Ranged attack") including [attack spells](/wiki/Attack_spell "Attack spell"), [wands](/wiki/Wand "Wand"), and/or [projectiless](/wiki/Projectiles "Projectiles") can mitigate the threat of his weapon attack and infectious bite, and elemental damage can be particularly effective. A sufficiently large stack of missile weapons such as [shuriken](/wiki/Shuriken "Shuriken"), [daggers](/wiki/Dagger "Dagger") or a [launcher](/wiki/Launcher "Launcher") and its corresponding ammo (preferably silver, if possible) can also make quick work of him. If you don't have a reliable strategy to defeat the Rat King, it is also viable to avoid him entirely - he generates asleep in a closed-off room that isn't necessary to travel through to get to the level's [luckstone](/wiki/Luckstone "Luckstone").

## Origin

[![Wikipedia](/images/thumb/f/f8/Fair-use-wikipedia-logo.png/50px-Fair-use-wikipedia-logo.png)](/wiki/File:Fair-use-wikipedia-logo.png "Wikipedia")

[Wikipedia](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Main_Page "wikipedia:Main Page") has an article about:

***[Rat king (folklore)](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rat_king_\(folklore\) "wikipedia:Rat king (folklore)")***

[![Wikipedia](/images/thumb/f/f8/Fair-use-wikipedia-logo.png/50px-Fair-use-wikipedia-logo.png)](/wiki/File:Fair-use-wikipedia-logo.png "Wikipedia")

[Wikipedia](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Main_Page "wikipedia:Main Page") has an article about:

***[The Nutcracker](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Nutcracker "wikipedia:The Nutcracker")***

In biology, a "rat king" refers to a group of rats that are accidentally knotted and sticked together at their tails and sometimes legs. It shares some similarities with siamese siblings, but as opposed to actual siamese twins, the rats are joined postnataly. Radiographical images show that the tails of the joined rats had fractures in their tails which healed, implying the rats were alive in that state for a prolonged time.

Various forms of media feature a "Rat King" character, often as a large humanoid rat depicted with a crown - the portrayal is based on the Mouse King from the 1892 two-act classical ballet *The Nutcracker*, who is sometimes called the Rat King in adaptations.

## Encyclopedia entry

At this moment two of the enemies' tirailleurs seized him by  
his wooden mantle, and the Mouse-King, squeaking from his seven  
throats, leaped in triumph towards him. Maria could no longer  
control herself. "Oh, my poor Nutcracker!" she cried, sobbing,  
and without being exactly conscious of what she did, grasped her  
left shoe, and threw it with all her strength into the thickest  
of the mice, straight at their king.  
\[ Nutracker and the Mouse-King, by E. T. A. Hoffmann,  
translated by Mrs. St. Simon ]

@ Rat King
Difficulty 14
Attacks

Weapon 3d4, Bite 1d6 lycanthropy

Base level 12
Base experience 296
Speed 12
Base AC 3
Base MR 30
Alignment -10 (chaotic)
Frequency (by normal means) Unique
Genocidable No
Weight 1450
Nutritional value 400
Size Medium
Resistances poison,sleep,level drain
Resistances conveyed None

The Rat King:

  • can swim.
  • has a head, a couple of arms, and a torso.
  • regenerates HP quickly.
  • is poisonous to eat.
  • is omnivorous.
  • is not a valid polymorphable form.
  • is male.
  • is normally generated hostile.
  • is nasty.
  • is strong.
  • likes gold.
  • can pick up weapons and food.
  • can be seen through infravision.
Reference EvilHack - monst.c, line 3114

The Rat King, @, is a unique monster that appears in EvilHack and Hack'EM. In Hack'EM, this version of the Rat King serves the same roles as the Rat King of SLASH'EM.

The Rat King is a strong and omnivorous human that is similar to a wererat, but does not shift from his humanoid form. He has regeneration, can be seen via infravision, is capable of swimming, and will pick up items and valuables.

The Rat King has a weapon attack and a lycanthropy-inducing bite, and possesses poison resistance, sleep resistance and drain resistance like other werecreatures.

The Rat King's corpse is poisonous to eat.

Contents

  • 1 Generation
    • 1.1 EvilHack
    • 1.2 Hack'EM
  • 2 Strategy
  • 3 Origin
  • 4 Encyclopedia entry

Generation

The Rat King is always generated hostile, and is not a valid form for normal polymorph.

The Rat King is always generated with a pair of high boots, a cloak of displacement, and a rustproof +1 to +3 scimitar of venom. He also has a 2⁄3 chance of generating with a ring of teleport control.

EvilHack

The Rat King only appears in The Sewers of Waterdeep variant of Mines' End, which is a sewage-filled level consisting of a series of rooms that are surrounded by long halls, including a treasure room that is only accessible with teleportation - he will always be generated in the throne room.

Hack'EM

The Rat King appears on the rat level as he does in SLASH'EM and other similar variants, though he can still generate with a ring of teleport control as in EvilHack.

Strategy

The Rat King is a formidable early-game opponent: He moves at the same base speed as an unburdened player, resists sleep and poison that some early characters can use to dispatch other foes, and his weapon and cloak make him difficult to attack in melee. Even characters that can consistently hit through the Rat King's AC, which is usually around 0, the displacement from his cloak will cause half of your attacks to miss - combined with the slowing effects of wading through sewage, this can easily prolong the fight and increase the odds of contracting lycanthropy, being poisoned by his scimitar, or simply taking excessive damage. A character with poison resistance, high MC and consistent damage output should be able to take him on, and an early source of flight or levitation can help prevent the sewage from constantly slowing down non-tortle characters.

Ranged attacks including attack spells, wands, and/or projectiless can mitigate the threat of his weapon attack and infectious bite, and elemental damage can be particularly effective. A sufficiently large stack of missile weapons such as shuriken, daggers or a launcher and its corresponding ammo (preferably silver, if possible) can also make quick work of him. If you don't have a reliable strategy to defeat the Rat King, it is also viable to avoid him entirely - he generates asleep in a closed-off room that isn't necessary to travel through to get to the level's luckstone.

Origin

Wikipedia has an article about:
Rat king (folklore)
Wikipedia has an article about:
The Nutcracker

In biology, a "rat king" refers to a group of rats that are accidentally knotted and sticked together at their tails and sometimes legs. It shares some similarities with siamese siblings, but as opposed to actual siamese twins, the rats are joined postnataly. Radiographical images show that the tails of the joined rats had fractures in their tails which healed, implying the rats were alive in that state for a prolonged time.

Various forms of media feature a "Rat King" character, often as a large humanoid rat depicted with a crown - the portrayal is based on the Mouse King from the 1892 two-act classical ballet The Nutcracker, who is sometimes called the Rat King in adaptations.

Encyclopedia entry

At this moment two of the enemies' tirailleurs seized him by
his wooden mantle, and the Mouse-King, squeaking from his seven
throats, leaped in triumph towards him. Maria could no longer
control herself. "Oh, my poor Nutcracker!" she cried, sobbing,
and without being exactly conscious of what she did, grasped her
left shoe, and threw it with all her strength into the thickest
of the mice, straight at their king.
[ Nutracker and the Mouse-King, by E. T. A. Hoffmann,
translated by Mrs. St. Simon ]

The '''Rat King''', {{monsym|Rat King (EvilHack)}}, is a [[unique]] [[monster]] that appears in [[EvilHack]] and [[Hack'EM]]. In Hack'EM, this version of the Rat King serves the same roles as [[The Rat King (SLASH'EM)|the Rat King]] of [[SLASH'EM]].

The Rat King is a [[strong]] and [[omnivorous]] [[Human (monster attribute)|human]] that is similar to a [[wererat]], but does not shift from his [[humanoid]] form. He has [[regeneration]], can be seen via [[infravision]], is capable of [[swimming]], and will pick up items and valuables.

The Rat King has a weapon attack and a [[lycanthropy]]-inducing bite, and possesses [[poison resistance]], [[sleep resistance]] and [[drain resistance]] like other werecreatures.

The Rat King's [[corpse]] is [[poisonous]] to eat.

==Generation==
The Rat King is always generated hostile, and is not a valid form for normal [[polymorph]].

The Rat King is always generated with a pair of [[high boots]], a [[cloak of displacement]], and a [[rustproof]] +1 to +3 [[scimitar]] [[Object properties#EvilHack|of venom]]. He also has a {{frac|2|3}} chance of generating with a [[ring of teleport control]].

===EvilHack===
The Rat King only appears in The Sewers of Waterdeep variant of [[Mines' End]], which is a [[sewage]]-filled level consisting of a series of rooms that are surrounded by long halls, including a treasure room that is only accessible with [[teleportation]] - he will always be generated in the throne room.

===Hack'EM===
The Rat King appears on the [[rat level]] as he does in SLASH'EM and other similar variants, though he can still generate with a ring of teleport control as in EvilHack.

==Strategy==
The Rat King is a formidable early-game opponent: He moves at the same base [[speed]] as an unburdened player, resists sleep and poison that some early characters can use to dispatch other foes, and his weapon and cloak make him difficult to attack in melee. Even characters that can consistently hit through the Rat King's [[AC]], which is usually around 0, the [[displacement]] from his [[cloak]] will cause half of your attacks to miss - combined with the slowing effects of wading through sewage, this can easily prolong the fight and increase the odds of contracting lycanthropy, being poisoned by his scimitar, or simply taking excessive damage. A character with poison resistance, high [[MC]] and consistent damage output should be able to take him on, and an early source of [[flight]] or [[levitation]] can help prevent the sewage from constantly slowing down non-[[Tortle (starting race)|tortle]] characters.

[[Ranged attack]]s including [[attack spell]]s, [[wand]]s, and/or [[projectiles]]s can mitigate the threat of his weapon attack and infectious bite, and elemental damage can be particularly effective. A sufficiently large stack of missile weapons such as [[shuriken]], [[dagger]]s or a [[launcher]] and its corresponding ammo (preferably silver, if possible) can also make quick work of him. If you don't have a reliable strategy to defeat the Rat King, it is also viable to avoid him entirely - he generates asleep in a closed-off room that isn't necessary to travel through to get to the level's [[luckstone]].

==Origin==
{{wikipedia|Rat king (folklore)}}
{{wikipedia|The Nutcracker}}
In biology, a "rat king" refers to a group of rats that are accidentally knotted and sticked together at their tails and sometimes legs. It shares some similarities with siamese siblings, but as opposed to actual siamese twins, the rats are joined postnataly. Radiographical images show that the tails of the joined rats had fractures in their tails which healed, implying the rats were alive in that state for a prolonged time.

Various forms of media feature a "Rat King" character,  often as a large humanoid rat depicted with a crown - the portrayal is based on the Mouse King from the 1892 two-act classical ballet ''The Nutcracker'', who is sometimes called the Rat King in adaptations.

==Encyclopedia entry==
{{encyclopedia|
	At this moment two of the enemies' tirailleurs seized him by
	his wooden mantle, and the Mouse-King, squeaking from his seven
	throats, leaped in triumph towards him.  Maria could no longer
	control herself.  "Oh, my poor Nutcracker!" she cried, sobbing,
	and without being exactly conscious of what she did, grasped her
	left shoe, and threw it with all her strength into the thickest
	of the mice, straight at their king.
	   [ Nutracker and the Mouse-King, by E. T. A. Hoffmann,
		translated by Mrs. St. Simon ]
}}
